source.9a10b363:
twitter_data = json.loads(tweets)

#print(twitter_data[0].keys())

#keys to delete
keys = ['retweeted', 'source', 'entities', 'display_text_range', 'id_str','truncated','id', 'possibly_sensitive','favorited','extended_entities', 'in_reply_to_status_id', 'in_reply_to_status_id_str','in_reply_to_user_id', 'in_reply_to_user_id_str']
df = pd.DataFrame()
for dictionary in twitter_data:
    for key in keys:
        try:
            del dictionary[key]
        except KeyError:
           pass
    df = df.append(pd.DataFrame.from_dict([dictionary]), sort=False)
del keys
del dictionary
del key
    
#- Split dates.    
A = df["created_at"].str.split(" ", expand = True)
A = A.drop(4, axis=1)
AHeaders = ["Year", "Month", "Day"]
A.columns = ["Weekday", "Month", "Day", "Time", "Year"]
df = pd.concat([df, A], axis=1)
df = df.drop("created_at", axis=1)
del A
del AHeaders

#- Remove mentions from tweets.
for words in df["full_text"]:
    ssplit2 = ""
    ssplit = words.split()
    for word in ssplit:
        if word[0] == "@":
            word = ""
        else:
            ssplit2 = ssplit2 + " " + word
    if ssplit2[0] == " ":
        ssplit2 = ssplit2[1:]    
    else:
        ssplit2 = ssplit2                
    df.loc[df.full_text == words, "full_text"] = ssplit2  
del words
del ssplit2
del ssplit
del word
#----- Make integers out of strings in numerical columns
for word in df["favorite_count"]:
    df.loc[df.favorite_count == word, "favorite_count"] = int(word)

df["Hour"] = df["Time"].apply(lambda hour: hour[:2]+":00")
source.b51d3aa5:
Years = df["Year"].unique().tolist()
df_temp = df.groupby(["Month"]).apply(lambda column: column["Year"].value_counts()).unstack().reindex(["Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"]).reset_index()


df_temp.plot(x="Month", y=Years, kind="area", figsize=(20, 10))
source.9f15820a:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(20,10))
ax1 = fig.add_subplot(221)
ax2 = fig.add_subplot(222)
ax3 = fig.add_subplot(223)
ax4 = fig.add_subplot(224)

sns.countplot(x="favorite_count", data=df, order=df['favorite_count'].value_counts().index, ax=ax1)
plt.xlabel("Favorites")
sns.countplot(x="lang", data=df, order=df['lang'].value_counts().iloc[:5].index, ax=ax2)
plt.xlabel("Language")
sns.countplot(x="retweet_count", data=df, order=df['retweet_count'].value_counts().index, ax=ax3)
plt.xlabel("Retweets")
sns.countplot(x="in_reply_to_screen_name", data=df, order=df["in_reply_to_screen_name"].value_counts().iloc[:10].index, ax=ax4)
plt.xticks(rotation=30)
source.8661969a:
RTs = 0
MyTs = 0
#- Find RTs.
for word in df["full_text"]:
    if word[:2] == "RT":
        RTs = RTs + 1
    else:
        MyTs = MyTs + 1 
df_temp = {'Retweets': [RTs], 
        'My_tweets': [MyTs]}
df_temp = pd.DataFrame(df_temp, columns = ['Retweets', 'My_tweets']).reset_index()
del RTs
del MyTs     

df_temp.plot(x="index", y=["Retweets", "My_tweets"], kind="bar")
source.7af3a4a6:
comments_text = str(df.full_text)
comments_mask = np.array(Image.open('../input/davidr/IMG_1065.png'))
plot_wordcloud(comments_text, comments_mask, max_words=400, max_font_size=120, 
               title = 'Most frequent words in tweets', title_size=25)
source.d49dce0b:
To extract your data from twitter, use the guide in this link: https://help.twitter.com/en/managing-your-account/how-to-download-your-twitter-archive
The data you'll recieve is in a .js-format which I found a bit tricky to work with. I tried using the json-module, but since it isn't a Proper json-file I got several different decoding errors that differed depending on how I tried to do it. If someone could give me insight on how to read the .js-file to directly create the string I use to create a list of dictionarys I'd appriciate it very much.

Anyway, I did it by copying and pasteing the text in the .js-file as a string. (a snippet can be seen here just to get an idea of how the data from twitter actually looks)
source.5e28ee9d: It's pretty clear in the graph above - but just to further drive home the point we can see that my interest in tweeting has fluctuated over the years and took a big dip in 2016 (which happens to be the year I got married!).
source.0259b652:
It seems pretty clear that most of the discussions are occuring before lunch time! Hopefully mostly on my commute and on breaks! ;-) Then there is a clear dip during the afternoon before it picks up on the commute home from works.
There has been very few tweets made by me during night time - but what the hell is going on with those between 04:00 and 05:00? (*Each hour in the graph stands a whole hour -> 04:00:00 == 04:00-04:59:59
source.b8b0cc7c: Lastly, for the fun of it! Let's attempt to create a word cloud within a picture myself. First let's define a function (That I have mostly borrowed from https://www.kaggle.com/aashita/, thank you very much!)
source.bd659761: Phew - at least it seems like my tweets are Mostly my own. Good! Because I hardly am able to generate more favorites on the things I retweet! ;-)
source.97312969: But how does it look from month to month? Can we see some clear trends here?
source.8f23fcaa:
Very cool! Looking all relaxed with my drink and all. But looking at the words it seems to include alot of words I've probably only used once. So I better get tweetin' if this is to make any sense.

Anyways! Thanks for checking out my kernel! I hope it can be of use to someone and as I stated earlier - all feedback is appriciated! (Especially when it comes to reading the actual .js-file instead of copying and pasteing!)
source.9431d063: But we can find out more cool stuff here! Like how many interacts with my tweets, who am I tweeting @ and in what language?
source.a0021894: # Gaining insight from my twitter data
source.7ac9dbe7: When I had my string I used the json-module to create a list of dictionarys that I used to create a dataframe containing what I wanted.
source.2e4742ef: # Word cloud of frequently used words
source.96f9eeb0:
# Table of Contents
1. [Part 1 - Extracting data from twitter](#ch1)
1. [Part 2 - Gaining insight from my twitter data](#ch2)
1. [Part 3 - Word cloud of frequently used words](#ch3)
source.f805dec6: Are my words even my own? Let's find out.
source.a781883f: Someting is a bit fishy here! Especially with the ones from 2015. My guess is that there is something weird going on with the timestamp here.
source.d53e028b:
Hello and welcome to my kernel! Here I'm going to analyse my twitter data and find out excactly how few people that are interested in my thougths on social media. I'm also going to make a cool word cloud with my most frequently used words on twitter.

Enjoy! I hope it can be of assistance and if anyone have got feedback on how to make this kernel better it would be greatly appriciated!
source.8a628c59: Instead of using the 40 000+ lines in my original .js-file I've already prepared my dataframe locally and will thus import it below:
source.0919fee4: Even though the x-ticks have disappeared we can clearly see that there is alot of tweeting goin on in january and then it gradually slows down and then takes a huge dip in the summer months, have a small uptick when the swedish vacation period is over, then slows down again just to be picked up when the temperatures starts to becoming close to zero and more time is spent indoors.
source.cda67f9b: It's pretty clear that I use my weekends to other things than using twitter. But at what time of the day am I tweeting?
source.4954615a:
I mean.. so this is just depressing right here! It actually seems to be me just screaming into the void with almost 1200 tweets written NONE have been retweeted more than 3 times and not even 20% even gets one favorite.. We can also see who I'm usually talking to... ...myself! And other than that it seems to mostly bli sports journalists from Sweden.

*It also seems that Twitters language interpreter sometimes have a hard time separating the nordic languages - because I'm pretty sure I haven't tweeted anything in norwegian or danish!
source.4cf2a22a: Which days do I try to make my voice heard?
